thread.title: Tribe's Anderson, Houston-Carson gain weekly CAA football honors; No. 13 CNU blanks No. 18 Catholic in field hockey
thread.title_full: Tribe's Anderson, Houston-Carson gain weekly CAA football honors; No. 13 CNU blanks No. 18 Catholic in field hockey

title: Tribe's Anderson, Houston-Carson gain weekly CAA football honors; No. 13 CNU blanks No. 18 Catholic in field hockey
text:
Tribe's Anderson, Houston-Carson gain weekly CAA football honors; No. 13 CNU blanks No. 18 Catholic in field hockey Compiled by Daily Press 
COLLEGE FOOTBALL: 
William and Mary’s Kendell Anderson was named the Colonial Athletic Association Offensive Player of the Week after rushing for 174 yards and two touchdowns on 27 carries in Saturday’s win over New Hampshire. 
The Tribe’s DeAndre Houston-Carson was named the CAA Special Teams Player of the Week following the ninth punt block of his career, which came in the fourth quarter. ... 
W&M climbed to 17th, Richmond to 11th and James Madison to fourth in the FCS Stats media poll after victories Saturday. 
In the FCS coaches’ poll, the Tribe rose to 16th, the Spiders to 12th and the Dukes to third. 
MORE COLLEGES: 
Field hockey: 
Christopher Newport (11-2), ranked 13th in Division III, beat No. 18 Catholic 1-0 on Brittan Muir’s goal in the 34th minute, late in the first half. Lauren Cheatham, a Denbigh High graduate, had the assist. 
Bailey Lien made four saves for the shutout as the Captains outshot the Cardinals 16-6, dropping Catholic to 10-4. 
Women’s tennis: 
Virginia senior Julia Elbaba took the Intercollegiate Tennis Association Atlantic Regional singles title in Lynchburg, dominating Virginia Tech’s Caroline Daxhelet 6-1, 6-1. 
Danielle Collins and freshman Meghan Kelley then beat fellow Cavaliers Elbaba and Skylar Morton 6-3, 6-1 in the doubles final. 
Elbaba gained a spot in the ITA National Indoor Championships, joining Collins — the Riviera All-American champ. Collins and Kelley earned a berth in the national indoor doubles bracket. 
Men’s tennis: 
Old Dominion sophomore Adam Moundir and Virginia Tech’s Joao Monteiro earned berths in the ITA Atlantic Regional singles final in Blacksburg. 
Moundir defeated Mac Styslinger of U.Va. 7-5, 6-4 and Jaan Kononov of Maryland Baltimore County 2-6, 6-3, 6-2. Monteiro handled ODU’s Michael Weindl 6-2, 6-1 and Penn State’s Aws Laaribi 6-0, 6-1. 
In doubles, the title match also will pit the Monarchs and Hokies: Moundir and Aziz Kijametovic against Edoardo Tessaro and Amerigo Contini. 
The ODU tandem ousted Monteiro and Andreas Bjerrehus 7-5, 6-1, while Tessaro and Contini beat Danil Zelenkov and Julius Tverijonas 6-4, 6-4. 
PRO BASKETBALL: 
Briante Weber, a Great Bridge High graduate, signed to play with the Miami Heat. He well could be headed to Sioux Falls, S.D., to play in the NBA Developmental League (D-League). 
Weber almost set the all-time NCAA steals record before being sidelined with a serious knee injury during his VCU senior season of 2014-15, but he has rehabbed from that injury enough to compete again. 
PRO BASEBALL: 
Former Norfolk Tides and Baltimore Orioles center fielder Jason Pridie, a 2013 International League All-Star, has been released by the Oakland Athletics so he can play in Japan.
